# Semantic Web

Where the Semantic web is:

<img src="/assets/OxaJbLWokoasxYxH3V5cXgiSnYk.png" src-width="906" src-height="614" align="center"/>

Why we need GOFAI when we have GPT: GPT can make mistakes, we still need solid data and knowledge representation

# Welcomeï¼šVision & Internet&WWW

## The Vision 

### Paul Otlet  

Paul Otlet was often called a founding father of the World Wide Web.

> He envisioned organizing all human knowledge and making it accessible through a global network.

He created <b>The Mundaneum: Hierarchical Modelling </b>to index the world's knowledge

### Vannevar Bush  

Vannevar Bush published the article "As we may think" and, and proposed <b>the Memex</b>

Memex's core idea: <b>associative linking</b>

â€”â€”When viewing one item, another item related could instantly be recalled

### Douglas Engelbart  

Douglas Engelbart published "Augmenting human intellect: A Conceptual Framework" in 1962

He created oNLine System- NLS 

Breakthrough:

- The mouse: allow intuitive interaction with digital content.
- Word processing: Enabled users to edit and manage text documents interactively.
- Data sharing: Allowed multiple users to access and collaborate on information simultaneously.
- Hypertext: Introduced the idea of linking pieces of information for non-linear navigation.

### Ted Nelson

He coined the term â€œhypertextâ€ in the early 1960s to describe non-linear, linked writing.

Project Xanadu was the first hypertext system ever proposed.

â€œEverything is deeply intertwingledâ€ â€” <em>Ted Nelson</em>

## The Internet  

### Internet Architecture  and Standards  

<em>development and progress on the internet is achieved in a  </em><em>decentralised</em><em> way, there is a need for governance and standardisation</em>

1. IETF internet engineering task force hosted by Internet Society

- provides a forum for interested parties to work on 

specifications for internet technology specifications

- published RFCs that serve as foundation of the World Wide Web, eg: Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) and Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP)

1. RFCs Request for Comments â€”â€” specifications mentioned above

It is an example of managing standardization in fast developing surroundings

1. Postelâ€™s Robustness Principle

be conservative in what you do, 

be liberal in what you accept from others

1. ICANN Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers

- IP address space allocation
- Protocol identifier assignment
- generic and country code top-level Domain Name System management
- root server system management functions.

1. IANA Internet Assigned Number Authority

- coordinates the allocation of IP addresses 
- administers the Domain Name System (DNSï¼‰

> The DNS is hierarchically organised and provides means to map from hostnames to IP addresses

### The Network Effect

Metcalfeâ€˜s Law: 

1. the cost of the network  was directly proportional to the number of cards  installed
2. the value of the network was  proportional to the square of the number of users.

## ï¼Web æ¶æ„æ ¸å¿ƒ (Web Architecture)

<b>è¿™æ˜¯æœ¬ç« æœ€é‡è¦çš„è€ƒè¯•è€ƒç‚¹ã€‚</b>

### 4.1 èµ„æº (Resources)

èµ„æºæ˜¯ Web ä¸Šè®¨è®ºçš„ä»»ä½•äº‹ç‰©ï¼ˆæŠ½è±¡çš„æˆ–å…·ä½“çš„ï¼‰ã€‚

- <b>Information Resources</b>: æ¯”å¦‚ç”µå­æ–‡æ¡£ã€å›¾ç‰‡ã€æ–‡ä»¶ã€‚ 
- <b>Non-information Resources</b>: æ¯”å¦‚äººã€æˆ¿é—´ã€æŠ½è±¡æ¦‚å¿µã€‚ 

### 4.2 URI (Uniform Resource Identifier)

URI æ˜¯èµ„æºçš„åç§°/æ ‡è¯†ç¬¦ã€‚ 

<b>Name</b> vs. <b>Thing</b>:

- <b>URI</b> æ˜¯ <b>Name</b>ï¼ˆæ ‡è¯†ç¬¦ï¼‰ã€‚ 
- <b>Resource</b> æ˜¯ <b>Thing</b> æœ¬èº«ã€‚

URI çš„é€šç”¨è¯­æ³•ç»“æ„ (Generic Syntax): 

$$Scheme : // Authority / Path ? Query \# Fragment$$

- <b>Scheme</b>: æŒ‡å®šåè®®ç±»å‹ï¼ˆå¦‚ http, ftp, mailtoï¼‰ã€‚ 
- <b>Authority</b>: é€šå¸¸æ˜¯ä¸»æœºåï¼ˆHostnameï¼‰å’Œå¯é€‰ç«¯å£ã€‚ 
- <b>Path</b>: èµ„æºçš„å±‚çº§è·¯å¾„ã€‚ 
- <b>Query</b>: å˜é‡æ•°æ®ã€‚
- <b>Fragment</b>: å®šä½æ–‡æ¡£å†…çš„ç‰¹å®šéƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚

å¦‚æœé¢˜ç›®è¦æ±‚ä½ æ‹†è§£ `http://example.com:8042/over/there?name=ferret#nose`ï¼Œä½ å¿…é¡»ç”¨ä»¥ä¸‹è‹±æ–‡æœ¯è¯­æ ‡æ³¨ï¼š
- `http`: <b>Scheme</b> ()
- `example.com:8042`: <b>Authority</b> ()
- `/over/there`: <b>Path</b> ()
- `name=ferret`: <b>Query</b> ()
- `nose`: <b>Fragment</b> ()

## ï¼HTTP åè®® (Hypertext Transfer Protocol)

HTTP æ˜¯è¯­ä¹‰ç½‘äº¤äº’çš„æ ¸å¿ƒåè®®ã€‚

- <b>Stateless Protocol</b>ï¼ˆæ— çŠ¶æ€åè®®ï¼‰ï¼šæ¯ä¸ªè¯·æ±‚éƒ½æ˜¯ç‹¬ç«‹çš„ï¼ŒæœåŠ¡å™¨ä¸ä¼šä¿ç•™ä¹‹å‰çš„äº¤äº’ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚ <b>Every transaction is treated independently.</b>
- <b>Content Negotiation</b>: ç”¨æˆ·ä»£ç†ï¼ˆUser Agentï¼‰é€šè¿‡ Accept header è¡¨è¾¾åå¥½ï¼ŒæœåŠ¡å™¨é€šè¿‡ Content-Type å“åº”ã€‚
- <b>Request/Response Structure</b>: 
    1. <b>Start Line</b>: åŒ…å«æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆMethod, å¦‚ GETï¼‰ã€URIã€ç‰ˆæœ¬ã€‚ 
    2. <b>Header Fields</b>: é”®å€¼å¯¹æ ¼å¼ï¼ˆKey/Valueï¼‰ï¼Œæä¾›é¢å¤–ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚
    3. <b>Message Body</b>: ä¼ è¾“çš„å†…å®¹ï¼ˆå¯é€‰ï¼‰ã€‚ 

<b>ğŸŒŸ è€ƒè¯•å¿…èƒŒï¼šå¸¸è§çš„çŠ¶æ€ç  (Status Codes) </b>

- <b>200 OK</b>: è¯·æ±‚æˆåŠŸã€‚
- <b>301 Moved Permanently</b>: èµ„æºæ°¸ä¹…ç§»åŠ¨ï¼ˆå¸¸ç”¨äºè¯­ä¹‰ç½‘ä¸­çš„é‡å®šå‘ï¼‰ã€‚
- <b>303 See Other</b>: æŸ¥çœ‹å…¶ä»– URIï¼ˆå¯¹è¯­ä¹‰ç½‘åŒºåˆ†â€œç‰©â€å’Œâ€œæè¿°æ–‡æ¡£â€è‡³å…³é‡è¦ï¼‰ã€‚
- <b>404 Not Found</b>: èµ„æºæœªæ‰¾åˆ°ã€‚
- <b>500 Internal Server Error</b>: æœåŠ¡å™¨å†…éƒ¨é”™è¯¯ã€‚

<b>ğŸŒŸ è€ƒè¯•å¿…èƒŒï¼šHeader å­—æ®µä¸å†…å®¹åå•† (Content Negotiation)</b>

- <b>Accept</b>: ç”¨æˆ·ä»£ç†å‘Šè¯‰æœåŠ¡å™¨å®ƒæƒ³è¦çš„åª’ä½“ç±»å‹ï¼ˆMedia Typeï¼Œå¦‚ `text/turtle`ï¼‰ã€‚ 
- <b>Content-Type</b>: å“åº”ä½“ä¸­å®é™…çš„æ•°æ®æ ¼å¼ã€‚ 
- <b>Location</b>: ç”¨äºé‡å®šå‘çš„ç›®æ ‡åœ°å€ã€‚ 

> <b>Exam Question:</b>  
<em>Describe a complete HTTP interaction in which a client requests a non-information resource (e.g., a person) using content negotiation. Explain how the server responds and why specific status codes are used.</em>
> Below is a complete HTTP interaction between a client (user agent) and a server when the client requests a <b>non-information resource</b>. The interaction demonstrates <b>content negotiation</b>, <b>status codes</b>, and the distinction between a <em>thing</em> and its <em>description</em>, which is essential in the Semantic Web.
> 1. <b>Client sends the initial request</b>
> The client wants RDF data about a person identified by a URI.
Because the resource is a <em>non-information resource</em>, the server cannot directly return a representation of the person.
> <b>Request:</b>
> ä»£ç 
> ```text
GET /Alice HTTP/1.1
Host: example.org
Accept: text/turtle
```
> - <b>GET</b> is the HTTP method.
> - The client expresses a preference for <b>text/turtle</b> using the `Accept` header.
> - `/Alice` identifies a <b>non-information resource</b> (a real-world person).
> 1. <b>Server responds with a 303 redirect</b>
> Because `/Alice` is not an information resource, the server cannot return a representation of Alice herself.
Instead, it returns a <b>303 See Other</b> redirect to a document <em>describing</em> Alice.
> <b>Response:</b>
> ä»£ç 
> ```text
HTTP/1.1 303 See Other
Location: http://example.org/AliceDoc
```
> - <b>303 See Other</b> is used to separate the <em>thing</em> from its <em>description</em>.
> - The `Location` header points to the document that contains information about Alice.
> 1. <b>Client follows the redirect and requests the description document</b>
> The client now requests the URI provided in the `Location` header.
> <b>Request:</b>
> ä»£ç 
> ```text
GET /AliceDoc HTTP/1.1
Host: example.org
Accept: text/turtle
```
> 1. <b>Server returns the description document</b>
> The server can now return an <b>information resource</b> (a document), so it responds with <b>200 OK</b> and the requested media type.
> <b>Response:</b>
> ä»£ç 
> ```text
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: text/turtle

@prefix ex: <http://example.org/> .
ex:Alice a ex:Person ;
        ex:knows ex:Bob .
```
> - <b>200 OK</b> indicates success.
> - `Content-Type` matches the clientâ€™s `Accept` header.
> - The body contains RDF data describing Alice.

- <b>HTML</b>: æ ¸å¿ƒä»·å€¼åœ¨äº <b>Linking</b>ï¼ˆé“¾æ¥åˆ°å…¶ä»–æ–‡æ¡£ï¼‰ã€‚ 
- <b>XML</b>: äººæœºçš†å¯è¯»ï¼Œè¯­æ³•æ¯” HTML æ›´ä¸¥æ ¼ï¼Œæœ‰åŠ©äºæœºå™¨å¤„ç†ã€‚

- <b>æ¨èæµç¨‹ (Maturity Levels)</b>: WD (Working Draft) $\rightarrow$ CR (Candidate Recommendation) $\rightarrow$PR (Proposed Recommendation) $\rightarrow$ <b>REC (W3C Recommendation, æ­£å¼æ ‡å‡†)</b>ã€‚

# RDF 

## Introduction

1. Definition of RDF: a framework for expressing information about resources.ç”¨äºè¡¨ç¤ºèµ„æºçš„ä¿¡æ¯çš„æ¡†æ¶
2. Purpose of RDF: 
    - Designed for situations where <b>web information needs to be processed by applications</b>, not just displayed to humans.è®©åº”ç”¨å¯è¯»ä¿¡æ¯
    - Enables <b>semantic interoperability</b>: different applications can exchange data <b>without losing meaning</b>.è¯­ä¹‰äº’æ“ä½œæ€§ï¼Œä¸åŒåº”ç”¨äº¤æ¢ä¿¡æ¯

3. Linked Data Use Case
    - RDF allows <b>publishing and interlinking</b> data across the Web.
    - Example: Accessing `http://www.example.org/bob#me` might reveal that Bob knows Alice (via her IRI).
    - Following Aliceâ€™s IRI can lead to more dataâ€”friends, interests, etc.
    - This creates a <b>web of interconnected data</b>, known as <b>Linked Data</b>.

## Why use RDF

RDF is widely used across different communities for enabling <b>semantic interoperability</b>, <b>data enrichment</b>, and <b>cross-platform integration</b>.

> RDF è¢«å¹¿æ³›åº”ç”¨äºä¸åŒé¢†åŸŸï¼Œç”¨äºå®ç°<b>è¯­ä¹‰äº’æ“ä½œæ€§</b>ã€<b>æ•°æ®å¢å¼º</b>å’Œ<b>è·¨å¹³å°é›†æˆ</b>ã€‚

- <b>æ¼”å˜è¿‡ç¨‹</b>ï¼š
    - <b>Web 1.0</b>: åªè¯»ï¼ˆRead-Onlyï¼‰ï¼Œé™æ€ HTML ã€‚
    - <b>Web 2.0</b>: å¯è¯»å†™ï¼ˆRead-Write-Participateï¼‰ï¼Œç”¨æˆ·ç”Ÿæˆå†…å®¹ï¼Œä½†æ•°æ®å­˜åœ¨äºâ€œå­¤å²›ï¼ˆSilosï¼‰â€ä¸­ï¼Œæœºå™¨éš¾ä»¥ç†è§£è¯­ä¹‰ ã€‚
    - <b>Web 3.0 (Semantic Web)</b>: <b>Web of Data</b>ã€‚ç›®æ ‡æ˜¯è®©æœºå™¨ä¸ä»…èƒ½å¤„ç†æ•°æ®ï¼Œè¿˜èƒ½â€œç†è§£â€æ•°æ®å«ä¹‰å¹¶è¿›è¡Œé€»è¾‘æ¨ç† ã€‚

- <b>æ ¸å¿ƒç†å¿µ</b>ï¼šå°†â€œæ–‡æ¡£çš„é“¾æ¥ï¼ˆWeb of Documentsï¼‰â€æå‡ä¸ºâ€œæ•°æ®çš„é“¾æ¥ï¼ˆWeb of Dataï¼‰â€ã€‚

## ï¼RDF Data Model

### Triples

- RDF expresses statements of resources as <b>triples</b>:

`<subject> <predicate> <object>`

- <b>æ¯ä¸ªtripleæè¿°a relationship between two resourcesï¼ˆsubject and objectï¼‰ï¼š</b> subject and objectæ˜¯èµ„æºï¼Œpredicateè¡¨ç¤ºå®ƒä»¬ä¹‹é—´çš„<b>directional</b>å…³ç³»æ–¹å‘ï¼Œç§°ä¸º <b>å±æ€§ï¼ˆpropertyï¼‰</b>ã€‚
- Triples form a <b>graph structure</b>: subjects and objects æ˜¯ <b>èŠ‚ç‚¹</b>; predicates æ˜¯è¿æ¥å®ƒä»¬çš„ è¾¹ï¼ˆarcsï¼‰
- Example: `<Bob> <is a friend of> <Alice>`   `<Mona Lisa> <was created by> <Leonardo da Vinci>`
- The same resource can be subject and object makes it possible to find connections between triples.
- RDF graphs can be queried using <b>SPARQL</b>.

1. <b>Subject (ä¸»è¯­)</b>: æè¿°çš„å¯¹è±¡ï¼ˆå¿…é¡»æ˜¯ <b>IRI</b> æˆ– <b>Blank Node</b>ï¼‰ã€‚
2. <b>Predicate (è°“è¯­)</b>: æè¿°çš„å±æ€§æˆ–å…³ç³»ï¼ˆå¿…é¡»æ˜¯ <b>IRI</b>ï¼‰
3. <b>Object (å®¾è¯­)</b>: å±æ€§çš„å€¼æˆ–å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå¯¹è±¡ï¼ˆå¯ä»¥æ˜¯ <b>IRI</b>ã€<b>Literal</b> æˆ– <b>Blank Node</b>ï¼‰ã€‚

> æ³¨æ„ï¼š è°“è¯­åªèƒ½æ˜¯ IRIï¼Œä¸èƒ½æ˜¯ Literal æˆ– Blank Node ()ã€‚

### IRIs (International Resource Identifiers)

- IRIs are <b>global identifiers</b> for resources (documents, people, concepts).
- URI vs. IRIï¼š<b>URI ä»…é™ ASCII å­—ç¬¦</b>ï¼›<b>IRI æ”¯æŒ Unicode</b>ï¼ˆå¦‚ä¸­æ–‡ã€å¾·è¯­å­—ç¬¦ï¼‰ï¼Œæ›´å…·å›½é™…åŒ–ã€‚(URIs are one form of IRI)
- IRIs can appear in <b>any position</b> of a triple.
- Example IRIs:
    - `http://dbpedia.org/resource/Leonardo_da_Vinci`
    - `http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/knows`

- è§£å¼•ç”¨ (Dereferenceability)ï¼šè¿™æ˜¯ Linked Data çš„æ ¸å¿ƒã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ HTTP IRIsï¼Œä½¿å¾—äººä»¬æˆ–æœºå™¨å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡æµè§ˆå™¨æŸ¥æ‰¾è¿™äº› ID å¹¶è·å–æ›´å¤š RDF æ•°æ® ã€‚<b>IRI ä¸åªæ˜¯åå­—ï¼Œå®ƒè¿˜èƒ½ç‚¹å¼€ã€‚</b>   ä½ ç‚¹å¼€å®ƒï¼Œå°±èƒ½çœ‹åˆ°å…³äºè¿™ä¸ªèµ„æºçš„æè¿°æ•°æ®ã€‚

### Literals

- <b>Literals</b>æ˜¯åŸºæœ¬å€¼ï¼ˆå¦‚æ•°å­—ã€å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€æ—¥æœŸç­‰ï¼‰ã€‚
- Typed using <b>XML Schema datatypes</b> (e.g. string, boolean, date).ä½¿ç”¨ `^^` è¿æ¥ XSD æ•°æ®ç±»å‹ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ `"247380"^^xsd:integer` 
- é‡è¦ç»†èŠ‚ï¼šå¦‚æœæ²¡æœ‰æ ‡ç­¾å’Œç±»å‹ï¼Œé»˜è®¤æ˜¯ `xsd:string` ã€‚
- They åªèƒ½å‡ºç°åœ¨<b> object position</b> of a triple.
- å­—ç¬¦ä¸² Literal å¯ä»¥å¸¦<b>language tags</b> (e.g. `"æå¥¥çº³å¤šÂ·è¾¾Â·æ–‡è¥¿"@zh`)

### Blank Nodes

- Represent <b>unnamed resources</b> without global identifiers. ä»£è¡¨â€œå­˜åœ¨æŸä¸ªä¸œè¥¿â€ï¼Œä½†è¿™ä¸ªä¸œè¥¿æ²¡æœ‰å…¨çƒå”¯ä¸€çš„ IRI  <b>Existential Quantification</b>
- å¯ä»¥å‡ºç°åœ¨ <b>subject or object</b> positions.
- <b>é€‚åˆæè¿°â€œå­˜åœ¨æŸä¸ªä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸æƒ³æˆ–ä¸èƒ½ç»™å®ƒä¸€ä¸ªå…·ä½“ IRIâ€çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œ</b>ä¾‹å¦‚â€œè’™å¨œä¸½èèƒŒæ™¯ä¸­çš„ä¸€æ£µæ ‘â€ã€‚
- Act like <b>anonymous variables</b> in a graph.<b>åŒ¿åå˜é‡</b>ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºâ€œæœ‰è¿™ä¹ˆä¸€ä¸ªä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œä½†ä¸å‘½åå®ƒâ€ã€‚
- å…¶èº«ä»½ä»…åœ¨å½“å‰å›¾ä¸­æœ‰æ•ˆï¼ˆLocal Identityï¼‰ï¼Œé‡æ–°å‘å¸ƒæ—¶ IDï¼ˆå¦‚ `_:bn0`ï¼‰å¯èƒ½ä¼šå˜ ()ã€‚

### é“¾æ¥æ•°æ®åŸåˆ™ (Linked Data Principles) 

Tim Berners-Lee æå‡ºçš„å››é¡¹åŸåˆ™ï¼š

1. Use URIs to name things
2. ä½¿ç”¨ <b>HTTP URIs</b>ï¼ˆä»¥ä¾¿æŸ¥æ‰¾ï¼‰ Use HTTP URIs so people (and machines) can look them up.ã€‚
3. æŸ¥æ‰¾æ—¶æä¾›æœ‰ç”¨ä¿¡æ¯ï¼ˆä½¿ç”¨ <b>RDF</b> æˆ– <b>SPARQL</b> åè®®ï¼‰When a URI is looked up, provide useful information using standards like RDF and SPARQL.
4. åŒ…å«<b>æŒ‡å‘å…¶ä»– URI çš„é“¾æ¥</b>ï¼ˆä»¥å‘ç°æ›´å¤šå†…å®¹ï¼‰Include links to other URIs to enable discovery of related things.

This is the foundation of what we now call the Knowledge Graph.

### Multiple Graphs

- RDF supports grouping triples into <b>named or unnamed graphs</b>.
- Each graph can be associated with an IRI (called the <b>graph name</b>).
- Enables <b>modular datasets</b> and <b>source attribution</b>.
- Example:
    - Graph 1: Social data about Bob â†’ `http://example.org/bob`
    - Graph 2: Wikidata info about Leonardo â†’ `https://www.wikidata.org/...`

- RDF doesnâ€™t enforce semantics of graph namesâ€”interpretation relies on <b>community conventions</b>.

### RDF vs. Relational vs. NoSQL

# Turtle

## ğŸš€ Quick Recall: Turtle Summary

Turtle is a readable syntax for writing RDF (Resource Description Framework) data. All RDF data is just a set of <b>triples</b>: <b>Subject</b>, <b>Predicate</b>, <b>Object</b>, ending with a <b>period (</b><b>.</b><b>)</b>.

- <b>IRIs</b> (resources) are written in angle brackets: `<http://...>`.
- <b>Literals</b> (values) are in quotes:
    - `"Aachen"@de` (string with a language tag).
    - `123` (auto-detected as `xsd:integer`).
    - `4.7` (auto-detected as `xsd:decimal`).
    - `true` / `false` (auto-detected as `xsd:boolean`).
    - `"1985-07-22"^^xsd:date` (an explicit datatype).

### <b>Shortcuts are essential:</b>

- `@prefix` defines shortcuts for long IRIs (e.g., `rdfs:label`).
- `@base` sets a default IRI "folder" for relative IRIs (e.g., `<Aachen>`).
- <b>Semicolon (</b><b>;</b><b>)</b> repeats the <b>Subject</b> for a new Predicate-Object pair.
- <b>Comma (</b><b>,</b><b>)</b> repeats the <b>Subject</b> AND <b>Predicate</b> for a new Object.
- `a` is a shortcut for the predicate `rdf:type` (used to assign a class).

### <b>Complex Data:</b>

- <b>Blank Nodes</b>: Resources without an IRI. Written as `_:name` or anonymously with `[ ... ]`.
- <b>Collections (Lists)</b>: Ordered lists, written with parentheses `( ... )`. This is a shortcut for the underlying `rdf:first`/`rdf:rest`/`rdf:nil` structure.

---

## ğŸ“š Detailed Notes for Relearning

Here are structured notes based on your notebook, designed for in-depth relearning.

### Introduction to RDF and Serializations

- <b>RDF (Resource Description Framework)</b>: A framework for modeling information as <b>triples</b> (Subject, Predicate, Object). These triples form a graph.
- <b>Serializations</b>: Concrete syntaxes for storing and exchanging RDF graphs. The notebook compares three:
    - <b>RDF/XML</b>: The oldest, XML-based, and very verbose.
    - <b>JSON-LD</b>: A JSON-based format, popular for web APIs.
    - <b>Turtle (Terse RDF Triple Language)</b>: A text-based, compact, and highly human-readable syntax. It is the focus of this notebook.

### Turtle Syntax Basics

#### The Triple

The fundamental unit is the <b>triple</b>, which consists of a <b>Subject</b>, <b>Predicate</b>, and <b>Object</b>, followed by a <b>period (</b><b>.</b><b>)</b>.

- <b>Subject</b>: The resource being described (an IRI or blank node).
- <b>Predicate</b>: A property of the subject (always an IRI).
- <b>Object</b>: The value of the property (an IRI, literal, or blank node).
- <b>IRIs</b> (Internationalized Resource Identifiers) are always enclosed in angle brackets (`<>`).

<b>Example:</b>

ä»£ç æ®µ

```text
<http://dbpedia.org/resource/Aachen> <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label> "Aachen"@de .
```

- <b>Subject</b>: `<http://dbpedia.org/resource/Aachen>`
- <b>Predicate</b>: `<http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label>`
- <b>Object</b>: `"Aachen"@de`

#### Literals (The Object)

Literals represent concrete data values like strings, numbers, or dates.

- <b>Simple Literals (Strings)</b>: Enclosed in double quotes (`"..."`). Without a tag, they default to `xsd:string`.
- <b>Language Tags</b>: Added to strings with `@` (e.g., `"Aachen"@de`, `"Oche"@ksh`). These become the datatype `rdf:langString`.
- <b>Explicit Datatypes</b>: Added with `^^` followed by the datatype's IRI (e.g., `"29.99"^^<http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#decimal>`).
- <b>Datatype Abbreviations (Shortcuts)</b>: Turtle automatically recognizes common types without `^^`:
    - `123` is interpreted as `xsd:integer`.
    - `-5` is interpreted as `xsd:integer`.
    - `4.7` is interpreted as `xsd:decimal`.
    - `1.6E2` is interpreted as `xsd:double`.
    - `true` and `false` are interpreted as `xsd:boolean`.

#### Whitespace

Spaces, tabs, and line breaks are largely ignored outside of IRIs and literals. This allows you to format your code for readability.

---

### Abbreviations and Shortcuts (Making Turtle Terse)

#### ` @prefix`

- <b>Motivation</b>: To avoid repeating long namespace IRIs (like `http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#`).
- <b>Function</b>: The `@prefix` directive binds a short prefix label (e.g., `rdfs:`) to a full namespace IRI.
- <b>Example</b>:
    - `@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .`
    - Now, `rdfs:label` is a valid shortcut for `<http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label>`.

#### Semicolon (`;`)

- <b>Motivation</b>: To avoid repeating the <b>Subject</b> when describing multiple properties of the same resource.
- <b>Function</b>: The semicolon signals that the next predicate-object pair refers to the <b>same subject</b>. The block ends with a period (`.`).
- <b>Example</b>:
- ä»£ç æ®µ

```text
dbr:Aachen
    rdfs:label "Aachen"@de ;
    dbo:populationTotal 261472 .
```

- This defines two triples, both with `dbr:Aachen` as the subject.

#### Comma (`,`)

- <b>Motivation</b>: To avoid repeating the <b>Subject and Predicate</b> when a property has multiple values.
- <b>Function</b>: The comma signals that the next <b>Object</b> refers to the <b>same subject and predicate</b>.
- <b>Example</b>:
- ä»£ç æ®µ

```text
dbr:Aachen
    rdfs:label "Aachen"@de, "Oche"@ksh ;
    dbo:populationTotal 261472 .
```

- This defines three triples. The comma creates two `rdfs:label` triples for `dbr:Aachen`.

#### ` @base`

- <b>Function</b>: Defines a base IRI for the document. This allows you to use <b>relative IRIs</b> (e.g., `<Aachen>`) which are automatically expanded by prepending the `@base` value.
- <b>Note</b>: This only affects IRIs in angle brackets (`<>`), not prefixed names (like `dbr:Aachen`).

#### `a` Keyword

- <b>Function</b>: `a` is a shortcut for the predicate `rdf:type`.
- <b>Usage</b>: It's used to assign a class (a type) to a resource.
- <b>Example</b>: `ex:maxMustermann a foaf:Person .` is identical to `ex:maxMustermann rdf:type foaf:Person .`.

#### Comments

- Comments start with `#` and continue to the end of the line. They are ignored by the parser.

---

### Advanced Data Structures

#### Blank Nodes

- <b>Concept</b>: Resources that do not have, or should not have, a global IRI. They are "unnamed nodes".
- <b>Syntax 1: Named Blank Nodes (</b><b>_:</b><b>):</b>
    - A label starting with `_:` (e.g., `_:myAddress`) can be used as a subject or object to reference the blank node <em>within the same document</em>.
    - Example:
    - ä»£ç æ®µ
    ```text
<Aachen> schema:address _:address1 .
_:address1 a schema:PostalAddress ;
           schema:streetAddress "Markt 39" .
```

- <b>Syntax 2: Anonymous Blank Nodes (</b><b>[ ]</b><b>):</b>
    - A more compact syntax using square brackets `[ ]`. This is often used when a blank node is the <em>object</em> of a triple.
    - All properties of the blank node are written directly inside the brackets.
    - Example (equivalent to the one above):
    - ä»£ç æ®µ
    ```text
<Aachen> schema:address [
     a schema:PostalAddress ;
     schema:streetAddress "Markt 39"
 ] .
```

- <b>Nested Blank Nodes</b>: You can nest `[ ]` structures inside each other to represent complex hierarchical data (e.g., a person, who works at a place, which has an address).

#### Collections (Lists)

- <b>Concept</b>: Used to represent <b>ordered</b> lists of elements.
- <b>The Turtle Shortcut </b><b>( )</b>:
    - An ordered list is written by enclosing elements in parentheses, separated by spaces.
    - Example: `dbo:neighboringMunicipality ( <Herzogenrath> <WÃ¼rselen> <Stolberg> ) .`
    - An empty list is `( )`, which is equivalent to `rdf:nil`.

- <b>The Underlying Structure</b>:
    - This `( )` syntax is just a shortcut. The parser translates it into a chain of nodes (usually blank nodes) connected by `rdf:first` (points to the list item) and `rdf:rest` (points to the next node in the chain).
    - The last node in the chain points to `rdf:nil` to signify the end of the list.

- <b>List Properties</b>:
    - <b>Ordered</b>: The order is preserved.
    - <b>Mixed Types</b>: Lists can contain IRIs, literals, and blank nodes.
    - <b>Nestable</b>: A list can contain another list as an element.

# SPARQL

## SPARQL `FILTER` å­å¥ è¯¦ç»†ç”¨æ³•æ€»ç»“

`FILTER` æ˜¯ SPARQL ä¸­ç”¨äº<b>å¯¹</b> <b>WHERE</b> <b>å­å¥åŒ¹é…çš„ç»“æœè¿›è¡ŒäºŒæ¬¡ç­›é€‰</b>çš„æ ¸å¿ƒå­å¥ï¼Œå®ƒåŸºäºæŒ‡å®šæ¡ä»¶ä¿ç•™ç¬¦åˆè¦æ±‚çš„æŸ¥è¯¢è§£ï¼Œè¿‡æ»¤æ‰ä¸ç¬¦åˆçš„è§£ã€‚å…¶æ ¸å¿ƒç‰¹ç‚¹æ˜¯ï¼š<b>ä¸å‚ä¸å›¾æ¨¡å¼çš„åŒ¹é…ï¼Œåªå¯¹åŒ¹é…åçš„å˜é‡å€¼æˆ–å›¾æ¨¡å¼å­˜åœ¨æ€§åšåˆ¤æ–­</b>ã€‚

### åŸºæœ¬è¯­æ³•ä¸ä½ç½®

1. <b>è¯­æ³•ç»“æ„</b>

```text
FILTER(æ¡ä»¶è¡¨è¾¾å¼)
```

1. <b>æ”¾ç½®ä½ç½®</b>
    - ç›´æ¥å†™åœ¨ `WHERE` å­å¥çš„å›¾æ¨¡å¼ä¹‹å
    - å¯åœ¨ `OPTIONAL` `UNION` ç­‰å­å¥å†…ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œä½œç”¨äºå¯¹åº”å­å¥çš„åŒ¹é…ç»“æœ

2. <b>æ ¸å¿ƒè§„åˆ™</b>
    - æ¡ä»¶è¡¨è¾¾å¼è¿”å› `true` æ—¶ï¼Œä¿ç•™å½“å‰æŸ¥è¯¢è§£ï¼›è¿”å› `false` æˆ– `error` æ—¶ï¼Œè¿‡æ»¤å½“å‰è§£
    - å¤šä¸ª `FILTER` å­å¥å¹¶åˆ—æ—¶ï¼Œ<b>é»˜è®¤æ˜¯ </b><b>AND</b><b> å…³ç³»</b>ï¼Œéœ€åŒæ—¶æ»¡è¶³æ‰€æœ‰æ¡ä»¶

### æ ¸å¿ƒç­›é€‰ç±»å‹åŠç”¨æ³•

#### æ•°å€¼æ¯”è¾ƒç­›é€‰

é’ˆå¯¹ `xsd:integer` `xsd:double` ç­‰æ•°å€¼ç±»å‹çš„å˜é‡ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨å¸¸è§æ¯”è¾ƒè¿ç®—ç¬¦ã€‚

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹</b>ï¼šç­›é€‰å¹´çº§å°äºç­‰äº 4 çš„å­¦ç”Ÿ

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>
SELECT ?studentName ?semester
WHERE {
    ?student a :Student ;
            :hasName ?studentName ;
            :hasSemester ?semester .
     FILTER(?semester <= 4)
}
```

#### å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ç­›é€‰

é’ˆå¯¹ `xsd:string` ç±»å‹çš„å˜é‡ï¼Œæ”¯æŒ<b>å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ¯”è¾ƒã€å‰ç¼€ / åç¼€åŒ¹é…ã€æ­£åˆ™åŒ¹é…</b>ç­‰æ“ä½œï¼Œé»˜è®¤<b>åŒºåˆ†å¤§å°å†™</b>ã€‚

1. åŸºç¡€å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ¯”è¾ƒ

ä½¿ç”¨ `=` `!=` æˆ– `STR()` å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆç¡®ä¿æ¯”è¾ƒçš„æ˜¯å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å€¼ï¼‰ï¼š

```text
# ç­›é€‰å§“åç­‰äº "Alice" çš„å­¦ç”Ÿï¼ˆåŒºåˆ†å¤§å°å†™ï¼‰
FILTER(?studentName = "Alice")
# ç­›é€‰å§“åä¸ç­‰äº "Bob" çš„å­¦ç”Ÿ
FILTER(?studentName != "Bob")
```

1. ä¸“ç”¨å­—ç¬¦ä¸²å‡½æ•°

1. æ­£åˆ™è¡¨è¾¾å¼åŒ¹é…

ä½¿ç”¨ `REGEX(?var, "æ­£åˆ™è¡¨è¾¾å¼", "æ ‡å¿—ä½")` å‡½æ•°ï¼ŒåŠŸèƒ½æ›´çµæ´»ï¼š

- æ ‡å¿—ä½ `i`ï¼šä¸åŒºåˆ†å¤§å°å†™ï¼›é»˜è®¤åŒºåˆ†å¤§å°å†™

```text
# ç­›é€‰å§“ååŒ…å« "ali" çš„å­¦ç”Ÿï¼ˆä¸åŒºåˆ†å¤§å°å†™ï¼‰
FILTER(REGEX(?studentName, "ali", "i"))
```

#### è¯­è¨€æ ‡ç­¾ç­›é€‰

é’ˆå¯¹å¸¦è¯­è¨€æ ‡ç­¾çš„å­—é¢é‡ï¼ˆå¦‚ `"cat"@en` `"çŒ«"@zh`ï¼‰ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ `LANG()` æˆ– `LANGMATCHES()` å‡½æ•°ï¼Œç­›é€‰æŒ‡å®šè¯­è¨€çš„å†…å®¹ã€‚

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹</b>ï¼šç­›é€‰è‹±æ–‡çš„è¯¾ç¨‹åç§°

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>
SELECT ?courseLabel
WHERE {
    ?course a :Course ;
        :hasLabel ?courseLabel .
    FILTER(LANG(?courseLabel) = "en")
}
```

#### æ•°æ®ç±»å‹ç­›é€‰

ä½¿ç”¨ `DATATYPE()` å‡½æ•°ï¼Œåˆ¤æ–­å˜é‡çš„ RDF æ•°æ®ç±»å‹ï¼Œç¡®ä¿æ•°æ®æ ¼å¼ç¬¦åˆè¦æ±‚ã€‚

- è¯­æ³•ï¼š`FILTER(DATATYPE(?var) = xsd:æ•°æ®ç±»å‹)`
- å¸¸è§æ•°æ®ç±»å‹ï¼š`xsd:string` `xsd:integer` `xsd:date`

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹</b>ï¼šç­›é€‰å¹´é¾„æ˜¯æ•´æ•°ç±»å‹çš„å­¦ç”Ÿ

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>
PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
SELECT ?studentName ?age
WHERE {
    ?student a :Student ;
        :hasName ?studentName ;
        :hasAge ?age .
    FILTER(DATATYPE(?age) = xsd:integer)
}
```

#### å˜é‡ç»‘å®šçŠ¶æ€ç­›é€‰

ä½¿ç”¨ `BOUND()` å‡½æ•°ï¼Œåˆ¤æ–­å˜é‡æ˜¯å¦è¢«æˆåŠŸç»‘å®šï¼ˆå³æ˜¯å¦æœ‰åŒ¹é…çš„å€¼ï¼‰ï¼Œå¸¸ä¸ `OPTIONAL` é…åˆä½¿ç”¨ã€‚

- `BOUND(?var)`ï¼šå˜é‡ `?var` ç»‘å®šåˆ™è¿”å› `true`
- `!BOUND(?var)`ï¼šå˜é‡ `?var` æœªç»‘å®šåˆ™è¿”å› `true`

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹</b>ï¼šç­›é€‰æœ‰é€‰ä¿®è¯¾ç¨‹çš„å­¦ç”Ÿï¼ˆ`?course` è¢«ç»‘å®šï¼‰

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>
SELECT ?studentName
WHERE {
    ?student a :Student ;
    :hasName ?studentName .
    OPTIONAL { ?student :attends ?course }
    FILTER(BOUND(?course))
}
```

#### å›¾æ¨¡å¼å­˜åœ¨æ€§ç­›é€‰

ç»“åˆ `EXISTS` / `NOT EXISTS` å…³é”®å­—ï¼Œåˆ¤æ–­<b>æŒ‡å®šå›¾æ¨¡å¼æ˜¯å¦å­˜åœ¨åŒ¹é…</b>ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯åŸºäºæ•´ä¸ªå›¾æ¨¡å¼çš„ç­›é€‰ï¼Œè€Œéå•ä¸ªå˜é‡å€¼ã€‚

1. æ ¸å¿ƒè¯­æ³•

```text
# å­˜åœ¨åŒ¹é…çš„å›¾æ¨¡å¼åˆ™ä¿ç•™
FILTER(EXISTS { å­å›¾æ¨¡å¼ })
# ä¸å­˜åœ¨åŒ¹é…çš„å›¾æ¨¡å¼åˆ™ä¿ç•™
FILTER(NOT EXISTS { å­å›¾æ¨¡å¼ })
```

1. å…³é”®è§„åˆ™

- å­å›¾æ¨¡å¼ä¸­å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨å¤–éƒ¨ç»‘å®šçš„å˜é‡ï¼ˆå¦‚å¤–éƒ¨çš„ `?student`ï¼‰ï¼Œå®ç°å…³è”ç­›é€‰
- å­å›¾æ¨¡å¼å†…ç»‘å®šçš„æ–°å˜é‡ï¼ˆå¦‚ `?lecture`ï¼‰ï¼Œä»…åœ¨å†…éƒ¨æœ‰æ•ˆï¼Œå¤–éƒ¨ä¸å¯è®¿é—®
- åªåˆ¤æ–­ â€œå­˜åœ¨ä¸å¦â€ï¼Œä¸å…³å¿ƒå­å›¾æ¨¡å¼åŒ¹é…çš„å…·ä½“å€¼

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹ 1</b>ï¼šç­›é€‰è‡³å°‘é€‰ä¿®ä¸€é—¨è¯¾çš„å­¦ç”Ÿï¼ˆå­˜åœ¨æ€§ï¼‰

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT ?studentNameWHERE {?student a :Student ;:hasName ?studentName .FILTER(EXISTS { ?student :attends ?course })}
```

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹ 2</b>ï¼šç­›é€‰ä¸é€‰ä¿®é€»è¾‘è¯¾çš„å­¦ç”Ÿï¼ˆä¸å­˜åœ¨æ€§ï¼‰

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT ?studentNameWHERE {?student a :Student ;:hasName ?studentName .FILTER(NOT EXISTS {?student :attends ?course .?course :hasName "Logic" .})}
```

## ä¸‰ã€ é€»è¾‘ç»„åˆå¤šæ¡ä»¶

å½“éœ€è¦åŒæ—¶æ»¡è¶³å¤šä¸ªç­›é€‰æ¡ä»¶æ—¶ï¼Œå¯ä½¿ç”¨<b>é€»è¾‘è¿ç®—ç¬¦</b>ç»„åˆï¼Œæ›¿ä»£å¤šä¸ªå¹¶åˆ—çš„ `FILTER` å­å¥ã€‚

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹</b>ï¼šç­›é€‰å¹´çº§â‰¤4 <b>ä¸”</b> å§“åä¸ä»¥ F å¼€å¤´çš„å­¦ç”Ÿ

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT ?studentName ?semesterWHERE {?student a :Student ;:hasName ?studentName ;:hasSemester ?semester .FILTER(?semester <= 4 && !STRSTARTS(?studentName, "F"))}
```

## å››ã€ æ ¸å¿ƒæ³¨æ„äº‹é¡¹

1. `FILTER` ä¸å‚ä¸å›¾æ¨¡å¼åŒ¹é…ï¼šå®ƒæ˜¯åœ¨ `WHERE` å­å¥åŒ¹é…å‡ºæ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½çš„è§£ä¹‹åï¼Œå†è¿›è¡Œç­›é€‰ï¼Œä¸ä¼šå½±å“å›¾æ¨¡å¼çš„åŒ¹é…è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚
2. ç©ºå€¼å¤„ç†ï¼šå¦‚æœç­›é€‰çš„å˜é‡æœªç»‘å®šï¼ˆæ— å€¼ï¼‰ï¼Œ`FILTER` ä¼šç›´æ¥è¿‡æ»¤è¯¥è§£ã€‚
3. æ€§èƒ½ä¼˜åŒ–ï¼šå¯¹äºå¤§è§„æ¨¡æ•°æ®é›†ï¼Œå°½é‡å…ˆé€šè¿‡å›¾æ¨¡å¼ç¼©å°åŒ¹é…èŒƒå›´ï¼Œå†ç”¨ `FILTER` ç­›é€‰ï¼Œé¿å…å¯¹å¤§é‡æ— æ•ˆè§£åšåˆ¤æ–­ã€‚

---

# SPARQL è¿›é˜¶å­å¥è¯¦ç»†æ€»ç»“ï¼ˆ`OPTIONAL`/`UNION`/`MINUS`/`FILTER NOT EXISTS`ï¼‰

æœ¬æ–‡æ¢³ç† SPARQL ä¸­å¤„ç†<b>å¯é€‰æ•°æ®ã€ç»“æœåˆå¹¶ã€ç»“æœå‰”é™¤</b>çš„æ ¸å¿ƒè¿›é˜¶å­å¥ï¼Œå¯¹æ¯”å®ƒä»¬çš„è¯­æ³•ã€é€»è¾‘å’Œé€‚ç”¨åœºæ™¯ï¼Œå¸®ä½ ç²¾å‡†æŒæ¡ç”¨æ³•ã€‚

## ä¸€ã€ `OPTIONAL`ï¼šåŒ¹é…å¯é€‰å±æ€§ï¼Œä¿ç•™åŸºç¡€ç»“æœ

### æ ¸å¿ƒä½œç”¨

é’ˆå¯¹ RDF æ•°æ®ä¸­<b>å¹¶éæ‰€æœ‰èµ„æºéƒ½å…·å¤‡çš„å±æ€§</b>ï¼ˆå¦‚éƒ¨åˆ†å­¦ç”Ÿæœ‰å­¦ç±å·ï¼Œéƒ¨åˆ†æ²¡æœ‰ï¼‰ï¼Œå°è¯•åŒ¹é…è¯¥å±æ€§ï¼›åŒ¹é…å¤±è´¥æ—¶ï¼Œä¸ä¸¢å¼ƒåŸºç¡€ç»“æœï¼Œä»…è®©å¯é€‰å˜é‡ä¿æŒ<b>æœªç»‘å®šçŠ¶æ€</b>ã€‚

### è¯­æ³•ç»“æ„

```text
SELECT ?åŸºç¡€å˜é‡ ?å¯é€‰å˜é‡
WHERE {# ä¸»æ¨¡å¼ï¼šå¿…é¡»åŒ¹é…çš„åŸºç¡€å›¾æ¨¡å¼ï¼ˆè¿”å›æ ¸å¿ƒç»“æœé›†ï¼‰
  ?ä¸»ä½“ a :ç±»å‹ ;:å±æ€§1 ?åŸºç¡€å˜é‡ .# å¯é€‰æ¨¡å¼ï¼šå°è¯•åŒ¹é…çš„å±æ€§ï¼Œå¤±è´¥ä¸å½±å“åŸºç¡€ç»“æœOPTIONAL {
    ?ä¸»ä½“ :å¯é€‰å±æ€§ ?å¯é€‰å˜é‡ .}}
```

### å…³é”®è§„åˆ™

- ä¸»æ¨¡å¼çš„ç»“æœæ˜¯åŸºç¡€ï¼Œ`OPTIONAL` ä»…ä¸ºåŸºç¡€ç»“æœ<b>è¡¥å……å¯é€‰å˜é‡çš„å€¼</b>ã€‚
- å¯é€‰å˜é‡æœªåŒ¹é…æ—¶ï¼Œåœ¨ç»“æœä¸­æ˜¾ç¤ºä¸º `null` æˆ–ç©ºå€¼ã€‚
- å¸¸ä¸ `BOUND()` é…åˆï¼Œç­›é€‰ â€œæœ‰ / æ— å¯é€‰å±æ€§â€ çš„èµ„æºï¼š
- sparql

```text
# ç­›é€‰ æ²¡æœ‰ å­¦ç±å·çš„å­¦ç”ŸFILTER(!BOUND(?matricNo))
```

- sparql

```text
# æ–°å¢åˆ—æ ‡è®°â€œæ˜¯å¦æœ‰å­¦ç±å·â€BIND(BOUND(?matricNo) AS ?hasMatric)
```

### å…¸å‹ç¤ºä¾‹

æŸ¥è¯¢æ‰€æœ‰å­¦ç”Ÿå§“åï¼Œ<b>å¯é€‰åŒ¹é…</b>å­¦ç±å·ï¼š

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT ?studentName ?matricNoWHERE {?student a :Student ;:hasName ?studentName .OPTIONAL {?student :hasMatriculationNumber ?matricNo .}}
```

## äºŒã€ `UNION`ï¼šåˆå¹¶å¤šä¸ªå›¾æ¨¡å¼çš„ç»“æœï¼ˆé€»è¾‘ ORï¼‰

### æ ¸å¿ƒä½œç”¨

å°†<b>å¤šä¸ªç‹¬ç«‹å›¾æ¨¡å¼</b>çš„åŒ¹é…ç»“æœåˆå¹¶æˆä¸€ä¸ªç»“æœé›†ï¼Œå®ç° â€œæ»¡è¶³ä»»æ„ä¸€ä¸ªæ¨¡å¼å³å¯â€ çš„é€»è¾‘ï¼Œæ˜¯ SPARQL å®ç° `OR` çš„æ ¸å¿ƒæ–¹å¼ã€‚

### è¯­æ³•ç»“æ„

```text
SELECT ?å…±äº«å˜é‡
WHERE {# æ¨¡å¼1ï¼šåŒ¹é…ç¬¬ä¸€ç±»èµ„æº{ ?ä¸»ä½“1 a :ç±»å‹1 ; :å±æ€§ ?å…±äº«å˜é‡ . }UNION# æ¨¡å¼2ï¼šåŒ¹é…ç¬¬äºŒç±»èµ„æº{ ?ä¸»ä½“2 a :ç±»å‹2 ; :å±æ€§ ?å…±äº«å˜é‡ . }}

### å…³é”®è§„åˆ™

1. <b>ç‹¬ç«‹è¯„ä¼°</b>ï¼šæ¯ä¸ª `{}` åŒ…è£¹çš„å­æ¨¡å¼ç‹¬ç«‹è®¡ç®—ï¼Œå­æ¨¡å¼é—´çš„å˜é‡ç»‘å®šäº’ä¸å½±å“ã€‚
2. <b>å…±äº«å˜é‡å¯¹é½ç»“æœ</b>ï¼šè‹¥å­æ¨¡å¼æœ‰åŒåå˜é‡ï¼ˆå¦‚ `?title`ï¼‰ï¼Œç»“æœä¼šæŒ‰è¯¥å˜é‡åˆ—åˆå¹¶ï¼›è‹¥æ— å…±äº«å˜é‡ï¼Œç»“æœä¸ºæ‰€æœ‰å­æ¨¡å¼çš„å˜é‡åˆ—å…¨é›†ã€‚
3. <b>é»˜è®¤ä¿ç•™é‡å¤é¡¹</b>ï¼šè‹¥å¤šä¸ªå­æ¨¡å¼äº§ç”Ÿå®Œå…¨ç›¸åŒçš„å˜é‡ç»‘å®šç»„åˆï¼Œä¼šé‡å¤æ˜¾ç¤ºï¼›éœ€å»é‡åˆ™ç”¨ `SELECT DISTINCT`ã€‚
4. <b>å¯åµŒå¥— / å¤šæ¨¡å¼åˆå¹¶</b>ï¼šæ”¯æŒ `{æ¨¡å¼1} UNION {æ¨¡å¼2} UNION {æ¨¡å¼3}` çš„å†™æ³•ã€‚

### å…¸å‹ç¤ºä¾‹

æŸ¥è¯¢<b>è¯¾ç¨‹çš„æ ‡é¢˜</b>å’Œ<b>åŠ©æ•™çš„ç ”ç©¶æ–¹å‘</b>ï¼Œç»Ÿä¸€æ”¾åœ¨ `?title` åˆ—è¾“å‡ºï¼š

```text

```

## ä¸‰ã€ `MINUS`ï¼šå‰”é™¤åŒ¹é…ç‰¹å®šæ¨¡å¼çš„ç»“æœï¼ˆé›†åˆå·®è¿ç®—ï¼‰

### æ ¸å¿ƒä½œç”¨

å…ˆè®¡ç®—ä¸»æ¨¡å¼çš„ç»“æœé›† `A`ï¼Œå†è®¡ç®—å‰”é™¤æ¨¡å¼çš„ç»“æœé›† `P`ï¼Œæœ€ç»ˆè¿”å› <b>A - P</b>ï¼ˆå±äº `A` ä½†ä¸å±äº `P` çš„ç»“æœï¼‰ï¼Œå®ç° â€œæ’é™¤ç¬¦åˆæŸæ¨¡å¼çš„è§£â€ çš„éœ€æ±‚ã€‚

### è¯­æ³•ç»“æ„

  ?ä¸»ä½“ a :ç±»å‹ ; :å±æ€§ ?ä¸»æ¨¡å¼å˜é‡ .# å‰”é™¤æ¨¡å¼ï¼šç»“æœé›† PMINUS {
    ?ä¸»ä½“ :ä¸æƒ³è¦çš„å±æ€§ ?ä»»æ„å˜é‡ .}}
```

### å…³é”®è§„åˆ™ï¼ˆæ ¸å¿ƒå‘ç‚¹ï¼‰

1. <b>åŸºäºå…±äº«å˜é‡åŒ¹é…</b>ï¼šåªæœ‰ä¸ä¸»æ¨¡å¼<b>åŒåçš„å˜é‡</b>ï¼ˆå¦‚ `?student`ï¼‰æ‰ä¼šå‚ä¸ â€œæ˜¯å¦å±äº Pâ€ çš„åˆ¤æ–­ã€‚
2. <b>éå…±äº«å˜é‡çš„ â€œä»»æ„ç»‘å®šâ€ é™·é˜±</b>ï¼š
    - è‹¥å‰”é™¤æ¨¡å¼ `P` åŒ…å«<b>ä¸»æ¨¡å¼æ²¡æœ‰çš„å˜é‡</b>ï¼ˆå¦‚ `?grade`ï¼‰ï¼ŒSPARQL ä¼š<b>ä»»æ„æ‰¾ä¸€ä¸ªå€¼ç»‘å®šç»™è¯¥å˜é‡</b>æ¥åˆ¤æ–­åŒ¹é…ã€‚
    - è¿™ä¼šå¯¼è‡´<b>æ„å¤–å‰”é™¤</b>ï¼šå“ªæ€•ä¸»æ¨¡å¼çš„è§£å’Œ P æ— å…³ï¼Œåªè¦èƒ½æ‰¾åˆ°ä»»æ„å€¼ç»‘å®šéå…±äº«å˜é‡ï¼Œå°±ä¼šè¢«åˆ¤å®šä¸º â€œå±äº Pâ€ å¹¶å‰”é™¤ã€‚

3. <b>ä¸ </b><b>UNION</b><b> çš„è¯­æ³•å¯¹æ¯”</b>ï¼š
    - `UNION` æ˜¯<b>å¤šä¸ªæ¨¡å¼éƒ½ç”¨ </b><b>{}</b><b> åŒ…è£¹</b>ï¼Œåœ°ä½å¹³ç­‰ï¼›
    - `MINUS` æ˜¯<b>ä¸»æ¨¡å¼å¯ç›´æ¥å†™ï¼Œä»…å‰”é™¤æ¨¡å¼ç”¨ </b><b>{}</b><b> åŒ…è£¹</b>ã€‚

### å…¸å‹ç¤ºä¾‹

æŸ¥è¯¢<b>ä¸å‚åŠ é€»è¾‘è¯¾</b>çš„å­¦ç”Ÿå§“åï¼š

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT ?studentNameWHERE {?student a :Student ; :hasName ?studentName .MINUS {?student :attends :LogicLecture .}}
```

### è¸©å‘æ¡ˆä¾‹ï¼ˆéå…±äº«å˜é‡å¯¼è‡´æ„å¤–å‰”é™¤ï¼‰

```text
# ä¸»æ¨¡å¼ï¼šæ‰€æœ‰å­¦ç”Ÿï¼ˆåªæœ‰ ?student / ?studentNameï¼‰?student a :Student ; :hasName ?studentName .# å‰”é™¤æ¨¡å¼ï¼šå¤šäº†éå…±äº«å˜é‡ ?gradeMINUS {?student :attends :LogicLecture ; :hasGrade ?grade .}
```

- è‹¥æ•°æ®åº“ä¸­<b>å­˜åœ¨ä»»æ„å­¦ç”Ÿçš„æˆç»©æ•°æ®</b>ï¼ˆå“ªæ€•ä¸æ˜¯å½“å‰å­¦ç”Ÿçš„ï¼‰ï¼Œ`?grade` ä¼šè¢«ç»‘å®šè¯¥å€¼ â†’ åˆ¤å®šå½“å‰å­¦ç”Ÿå±äº P â†’ æ„å¤–å‰”é™¤ã€‚

## å››ã€ `FILTER NOT EXISTS`ï¼šé€è§£æ•‘çš„å­˜åœ¨æ€§è¿‡æ»¤ï¼ˆç²¾å‡†æ’é™¤ï¼‰

### æ ¸å¿ƒä½œç”¨

å¯¹ä¸»æ¨¡å¼çš„<b>æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªè§£</b>ï¼Œç‹¬ç«‹æ£€æŸ¥ â€œæŒ‡å®šå­æ¨¡å¼æ˜¯å¦å­˜åœ¨åŒ¹é…â€ï¼›è‹¥ä¸å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œåˆ™ä¿ç•™è¯¥è§£ï¼›è‹¥å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œåˆ™è¿‡æ»¤è¯¥è§£ã€‚

### è¯­æ³•ç»“æ„

```text
SELECT ?ä¸»æ¨¡å¼å˜é‡
WHERE {# ä¸»æ¨¡å¼ï¼šç”Ÿæˆå¾…æ£€æŸ¥çš„è§£
  ?ä¸»ä½“ a :ç±»å‹ ; :å±æ€§ ?ä¸»æ¨¡å¼å˜é‡ .# è¿‡æ»¤æ¡ä»¶ï¼šæ£€æŸ¥å­æ¨¡å¼æ˜¯å¦ä¸å­˜åœ¨FILTER NOT EXISTS {
    ?ä¸»ä½“ :å­æ¨¡å¼å±æ€§ ?å†…éƒ¨å˜é‡ .}}
```

### å…³é”®è§„åˆ™

1. <b>é€è§£æ•‘ç‹¬ç«‹åˆ¤æ–­</b>ï¼šä¸ä¼šåƒ `MINUS` é‚£æ ·åšé›†åˆè¿ç®—ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯é’ˆå¯¹æ¯ä¸ªè§£å•ç‹¬éªŒè¯ã€‚
2. <b>å†…éƒ¨å˜é‡éš”ç¦»</b>ï¼šå­æ¨¡å¼ä¸­çš„å˜é‡ï¼ˆå¦‚ `?lecture`ï¼‰ä»…åœ¨å—å†…æœ‰æ•ˆï¼Œ<b>ä¸ä¼šå½±å“å¤–éƒ¨å˜é‡çš„ç»‘å®š</b>ï¼Œä¹Ÿä¸ä¼šå‡ºç° â€œä»»æ„ç»‘å®šâ€ çš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚
3. <b>æ•ˆç‡æ›´é«˜</b>ï¼šå¯¹ç®€å•çš„ â€œä¸å­˜åœ¨æŸå±æ€§â€ åˆ¤æ–­ï¼Œæ¯” `MINUS` æ›´ç›´è§‚ã€æ›´é«˜æ•ˆã€‚

### å…¸å‹ç¤ºä¾‹

æŸ¥è¯¢<b>ä¸å‚åŠ é€»è¾‘è¯¾</b>çš„å­¦ç”Ÿå§“åï¼ˆç²¾å‡†æ— å‘ï¼‰ï¼š

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT ?studentNameWHERE {?student a :Student ; :hasName ?studentName .FILTER NOT EXISTS {?student :attends ?lecture .?lecture :hasTitle "Logic" .}}
```

## äº”ã€ `MINUS` vs `FILTER NOT EXISTS` æ ¸å¿ƒå·®å¼‚å¯¹ç…§è¡¨

# SPARQL è¿›é˜¶æŸ¥è¯¢è¯­æ³•å…¨æ¢³ç†

æœ¬æ¬¡å­¦ä¹ çš„å†…å®¹åˆ†ä¸ºä¸¤å¤§æ¨¡å—ï¼š<b>ç»“æœé›†ä¿®é¥°ç¬¦</b>ï¼ˆæ’åºã€æˆªå–ã€å»é‡ï¼‰å’Œ<b>èšåˆå‡½æ•°</b>ï¼ˆç»Ÿè®¡ã€åˆ†ç»„ã€åˆ†ç»„è¿‡æ»¤ï¼‰ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬å‡ä½œç”¨äº `WHERE` å­å¥åŒ¹é…å‡ºçš„åŸå§‹ç»“æœé›†ï¼Œå’Œ SQL è¯­æ³•é€»è¾‘é«˜åº¦ä¸€è‡´ï¼Œä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯è¯¦ç»†æ‹†è§£ã€‚

## ä¸€ã€ ç»“æœé›†ä¿®é¥°ç¬¦ï¼ˆSolution Modifiersï¼‰

è¿™ç±»å­å¥çš„æ ¸å¿ƒä½œç”¨æ˜¯<b>è°ƒæ•´ç»“æœçš„å±•ç¤ºå½¢å¼</b>ï¼ˆæ’åºã€åˆ†é¡µï¼‰æˆ–<b>ç²¾ç®€ç»“æœå†…å®¹</b>ï¼ˆå»é‡ï¼‰ï¼Œæ‰§è¡Œé¡ºåºåœ¨ `WHERE` å­å¥ä¹‹åã€‚

### 1. `DISTINCT`ï¼šå»é™¤é‡å¤ç»“æœè¡Œ

- <b>ä½œç”¨</b>ï¼šåˆ é™¤ç»“æœé›†ä¸­<b>æ‰€æœ‰åˆ—å€¼å®Œå…¨ç›¸åŒ</b>çš„é‡å¤è¡Œï¼Œä»…ä¿ç•™å”¯ä¸€è¡Œã€‚
- <b>è¯­æ³•ä½ç½®</b>ï¼šç´§è·Ÿ `SELECT` å…³é”®å­—ï¼Œæ ¼å¼ä¸º `SELECT DISTINCT ?var1 ?var2`ã€‚
- <b>é€‚ç”¨åœºæ™¯</b>ï¼š`UNION` åˆå¹¶ç»“æœã€å¤šå¯¹å¤šå…³è”æŸ¥è¯¢æ—¶ï¼Œé¿å…é‡å¤æ•°æ®ã€‚

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹</b>ï¼šæŸ¥è¯¢å­¦ç”Ÿé€‰ä¿®çš„æ‰€æœ‰è¯¾ç¨‹åç§°ï¼Œå»é‡

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT DISTINCT ?courseNameWHERE {?student a :Student ;:attends ?course .?course :hasTitle ?courseName .}
```

### 2. `ORDER BY`ï¼šå¯¹ç»“æœé›†æ’åº

- <b>æ ¸å¿ƒè§„åˆ™</b>
    1. <b>ä½ç½®</b>ï¼š`WHERE` å­å¥ä¹‹åï¼Œ`LIMIT`/`OFFSET` ä¹‹å‰ã€‚
    2. <b>é»˜è®¤æ’åº</b>ï¼šå‡åºï¼ˆ`ASC`ï¼‰ï¼Œå¯æ˜¾å¼æŒ‡å®šå‡åº / é™åºï¼ˆ`ASC(?var)` / `DESC(?var)`ï¼‰ã€‚
    3. <b>å¤šå­—æ®µæ’åº</b>ï¼šå…ˆæŒ‰ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå˜é‡æ’åºï¼ŒåŒå€¼çš„è¡Œå†æŒ‰ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå˜é‡æ’åºï¼Œä»¥æ­¤ç±»æ¨ã€‚

- <b>è¯­æ³•</b>ï¼š`ORDER BY [ASC|DESC](?var1) [ASC|DESC](?var2)`

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹</b>ï¼šæŒ‰å­¦ç”Ÿå§“åå‡åºã€æˆç»©é™åºæ’åº

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT ?studentName ?scoreWHERE {?student a :Student ;:hasName ?studentName ;:hasScore ?score .}ORDER BY ASC(?studentName) DESC(?score)
```

### 3. `LIMIT` & `OFFSET`ï¼šç»“æœåˆ†é¡µæˆªå–

ä¸¤è€…éœ€æ­é…ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œå¸¸ç”¨äº<b>åˆ†é¡µæŸ¥è¯¢</b>ï¼Œä¾èµ– `ORDER BY` ä¿è¯ç»“æœé¡ºåºå›ºå®šï¼ˆæ— æ’åºæ—¶ï¼Œåˆ†é¡µç»“æœæ— æ„ä¹‰ï¼‰ã€‚

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹</b>ï¼šåˆ†é¡µæŸ¥è¯¢ç¬¬ 2 é¡µçš„å­¦ç”Ÿï¼ˆæ¯é¡µ 10 æ¡ï¼‰

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT ?studentNameWHERE {?student a :Student ;:hasName ?studentName .}ORDER BY ?studentName  # å¿…é¡»æ’åºï¼Œå¦åˆ™åˆ†é¡µç»“æœä¸å›ºå®šLIMIT 10 OFFSET 10
```

### ç»“æœé›†ä¿®é¥°ç¬¦æ‰§è¡Œé¡ºåº

`SELECT DISTINCT` â†’ `WHERE` åŒ¹é… â†’ `ORDER BY` æ’åº â†’ `OFFSET` è·³è¿‡ â†’ `LIMIT` æˆªå–

## äºŒã€ èšåˆå‡½æ•°ï¼ˆAggregate Functionsï¼‰

æ ¸å¿ƒä½œç”¨æ˜¯å¯¹ç»“æœé›†è¿›è¡Œ<b>ç»Ÿè®¡æ±‡æ€»</b>ï¼ˆå¦‚è®¡æ•°ã€æ±‚å’Œã€å¹³å‡å€¼ï¼‰ï¼Œå¯åˆ†ä¸ºã€Œå…¨å±€èšåˆã€å’Œã€Œåˆ†ç»„èšåˆã€ä¸¤ç±»ï¼Œå¸¸æ­é… `GROUP BY` å’Œ `HAVING` ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚

### å¸¸ç”¨èšåˆå‡½æ•°åŠåŠŸèƒ½

<b>å…³é”®æ³¨æ„</b>ï¼š`SUM`/`AVG` ä»…æ”¯æŒ `xsd:integer`/`xsd:double` ç­‰æ•°å€¼ç±»å‹ï¼Œéæ•°å€¼ç±»å‹éœ€å…ˆåšç±»å‹è½¬æ¢ã€‚

### å…¨å±€èšåˆï¼ˆæ—  `GROUP BY`ï¼‰

- <b>æ ¸å¿ƒé€»è¾‘</b>ï¼šèšåˆå‡½æ•°å¯¹ <b>æ•´ä¸ªç»“æœé›†</b> ç»Ÿä¸€è®¡ç®—ï¼Œæœ€ç»ˆä»…è¿”å› <b>1 è¡Œæ±‡æ€»æ•°æ®</b>ã€‚
- <b>å¼ºåˆ¶è§„åˆ™</b>ï¼š`SELECT` å­å¥ä¸­<b>ä¸èƒ½å‡ºç°éèšåˆå˜é‡</b>ï¼ˆåªèƒ½å†™èšåˆå‡½æ•°æˆ–å…¶åˆ«åï¼‰ã€‚
- <b>è¯­æ³•</b>ï¼š`SELECT èšåˆå‡½æ•° AS ?åˆ«å`

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹ 1</b>ï¼šç»Ÿè®¡æ•°æ®é›†ä¸­çš„å­¦ç”Ÿæ€»æ•°

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT COUNT(?student) AS ?totalStudentsWHERE {?student a :Student .}
```

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹ 2</b>ï¼šè®¡ç®—æ‰€æœ‰å­¦ç”Ÿçš„å¹³å‡æˆç»©

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>SELECT AVG(?score) AS ?averageScoreWHERE {?student a :Student ;:hasScore ?score .FILTER (xsd:integer(?score))  # ç¡®ä¿æˆç»©æ˜¯æ•°å€¼ç±»å‹}
```

### åˆ†ç»„èšåˆï¼ˆå¸¦ `GROUP BY`ï¼‰

- <b>æ ¸å¿ƒä½œç”¨</b>ï¼šæŒ‰æŒ‡å®šå˜é‡ / è¡¨è¾¾å¼çš„å€¼ï¼Œå°†ç»“æœé›†åˆ’åˆ†ä¸ºå¤šä¸ª<b>åˆ†ç»„</b>ï¼Œèšåˆå‡½æ•°é’ˆå¯¹æ¯ä¸ªåˆ†ç»„ç‹¬ç«‹è®¡ç®—ã€‚
- <b>æ ¸å¿ƒè§„åˆ™</b>
    1. `GROUP BY` åçš„å˜é‡æ˜¯<b>åˆ†ç»„ä¾æ®</b>ï¼ŒåŒä¸€åˆ†ç»„å†…è¯¥å˜é‡çš„å€¼å®Œå…¨ç›¸åŒã€‚
    2. `SELECT` å­å¥ä¸­<b>åªèƒ½å‡ºç°ä¸¤ç±»å†…å®¹</b>ï¼š`GROUP BY` é‡Œçš„å˜é‡ã€è¢«èšåˆå‡½æ•°åŒ…è£¹çš„å˜é‡ã€‚
    3. æ‰§è¡Œé¡ºåºåœ¨ `WHERE` ä¹‹åï¼Œ`HAVING` ä¹‹å‰ã€‚

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹</b>ï¼šæŒ‰æ•™æˆåˆ†ç»„ï¼Œç»Ÿè®¡æ¯ä½æ•™æˆçš„æˆè¯¾æ•°é‡

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT ?profName COUNT(?lecture) AS ?lectureCountWHERE {?prof a :Professor ;:hasName ?profName ;:teaches ?lecture .?lecture a :Lecture .}GROUP BY ?profName  # æŒ‰æ•™æˆå§“ååˆ†ç»„
```

### 4. `HAVING`ï¼šè¿‡æ»¤èšåˆåçš„åˆ†ç»„

- <b>æ ¸å¿ƒä½œç”¨</b>ï¼šé’ˆå¯¹ `GROUP BY` ç”Ÿæˆçš„åˆ†ç»„ç»“æœè¿›è¡Œç­›é€‰ï¼Œ<b>ä»…ä¿ç•™æ»¡è¶³æ¡ä»¶çš„åˆ†ç»„</b>ã€‚
- <b>ä¸ </b><b>FILTER</b><b> çš„æ ¸å¿ƒåŒºåˆ«</b>

- <b>å¼ºåˆ¶è§„åˆ™</b>ï¼š`HAVING` <b>å¿…é¡»å’Œ </b><b>GROUP BY</b><b> æ­é…ä½¿ç”¨</b>ï¼Œä¸èƒ½å•ç‹¬å‡ºç°ã€‚

<b>ç¤ºä¾‹</b>ï¼šç­›é€‰æˆè¯¾æ•° â‰¥ 3 çš„æ•™æˆåŠå…¶æˆè¯¾æ•°

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>SELECT ?profName COUNT(?lecture) AS ?lectureCountWHERE {?prof a :Professor ;:hasName ?profName ;:teaches ?lecture .?lecture a :Lecture .}GROUP BY ?profNameHAVING (COUNT(?lecture) >= 3)  # è¿‡æ»¤èšåˆåçš„åˆ†ç»„
```

### èšåˆç›¸å…³å­å¥æ‰§è¡Œé¡ºåº

`WHERE` åŒ¹é… â†’ `GROUP BY` åˆ†ç»„ â†’ èšåˆå‡½æ•°è®¡ç®— â†’ `HAVING` è¿‡æ»¤åˆ†ç»„ â†’ `ORDER BY` æ’åº â†’ `LIMIT`/`OFFSET` æˆªå–

## ä¸‰ã€ ç»¼åˆæŸ¥è¯¢ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼ˆå«æ‰€æœ‰è¯­æ³•ï¼‰

éœ€æ±‚ï¼šæŸ¥è¯¢å¹³å‡æˆç»© â‰¥ 80 çš„ç­çº§ï¼Œå±•ç¤ºç­çº§ IDã€å¹³å‡æˆç»©ã€æœ€é«˜æˆç»©ï¼ŒæŒ‰å¹³å‡æˆç»©é™åºæ’åºï¼Œå–å‰ 5 ä¸ªç­çº§ã€‚

```text
PREFIX : <http://example.org/university/>PREFIX xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>SELECT ?classId AVG(?score) AS ?avgScore MAX(?score) AS ?maxScoreWHERE {?student a :Student ;:belongsToClass ?classId ;:hasScore ?score .FILTER (xsd:integer(?score))  # ç¡®ä¿æˆç»©æ˜¯æ•°å€¼}GROUP BY ?classIdHAVING (AVG(?score) >= 80)  # è¿‡æ»¤å¹³å‡æˆç»©è¾¾æ ‡ç­çº§ORDER BY DESC(?avgScore)LIMIT 5
```

> `\texttt{[scheme] ":" [hierarchical part] ["?" [query]] ["#" [fragment]]}`
> - <b>scheme</b>ï¼šåè®®æˆ–æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå¦‚ `http`, `ftp`, `mailto`

1. IETF's task:
    - The IETF provides a forum for interested parties to work on  specifications for internet technology specifications 
    - The IETF also published RFCs that serve as foundation of the World Wide Web:  Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) and Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP)

    - IRIs are a generalization of URIs.

    - <b>RDF vs. æ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿ:</b> ä½ éœ€è¦çŸ¥é“ RDF æ˜¯ä¸€ç§<em>æ•°æ®</em>æŠ½è±¡ï¼Œä¸ç®¡ç†ç”µè„‘ä¸Šçš„<em>æ–‡ä»¶</em>ï¼ˆå¦‚åˆ›å»ºã€åˆ é™¤æ–‡ä»¶ï¼‰æ¯«æ— å…³ç³»ã€‚

> > - RDF is an <b>abstract data model</b> based on <b>triples</b>:
> &lt;subject&gt; &lt;predicate&gt; &lt;object&gt;\texttt{&lt;subject&gt; &lt;predicate&gt; &lt;object&gt;}
> - These triples form a <b>directed graph</b>, representing relationships between resources.

> 4. <b>The Query â€“ SPARQL</b>
> - SPARQL is the <b>query language</b> for RDF.
> - It allows users to ask questions like:
> - â€œWhich people are interested in paintings by Leonardo da Vinci?â€
> 5. <b>The Meaning â€“ RDFS / OWL</b>
> - <b>RDFS (RDF Schema)</b> and <b>OWL (Web Ontology Language)</b> define <b>semantics</b>:
    - Class hierarchies: â€œA is a type of Bâ€
    - Property relations: â€œX is part of Yâ€
> - They enrich RDF data with <b>logical meaning</b> and <b>inference capabilities</b>.
> 6. <b>The Rules â€“ SHACL / ShEx</b>
> - Used to <b>validate RDF data</b> against constraints:
    - Example: â€œA person must have exactly one birthdate.â€
> - SHACL and ShEx define <b>shapes</b> or <b>schemas</b> for RDF graphs.

2. About Turtle

<b>It is used to serialize RDF graphs in a human readable fashion.</b>  

1. About Url(Uniform Resource Identifier)
    - <b>Definition</b>: A URI is a <em>Uniform Resource Identifier</em>, used to name or identify resources.
    - <b>Purpose</b>: Serves as a unique name for any resourceâ€”documents, people, concepts, etc.
    - <b>Governance</b>: Defined and standardized by the <b>IETF</b> through <b>RFCs</b> (Request for Comments).

1. Verification of RDF
